front.p: All the coast line of the Northern part of New Zealand is fringed by a giant myrtle, which covers the cliffs and foreshores. This tree is the Pohutakawa Pohutakawa. Sharpe, in common with many settlers, misspells pōhutukawa. Colonial botanist Thomas Kirk claimed the species “is, perhaps, the most magnificent plant in the New Zealand flora” (The Forest Flora of New Zealand, 1889). of the natives, and the “Christmas tree” of the settlers, so called because at Christmas time it bursts out into a mass of crimson bloom, and is used to decorate the houses at that festive season. Its wood is very hard and durable, and is used for the ribs and knees of vessels, for which its strength and remarkable curvatures render it invaluable. The trunks are seldom more than 12ft. girth, but the spread of the huge twisted limbs is enormous, casting deep shadows around and underneath on the cliffs, and it often grows to a height of a hundred feet. It seems to delight in the most exposed places, where it spreads broad and low, and defies the tempest.

lg.l: Metrosideros Tomentosa, Metrosideros Tomentosa. The nineteenth century taxonomic name of pōhutukawa, now known as Metrosideros excelsa, which is derived from the ancient Greek words “metra” (heartwood) and “sideron” (iron).
All unlike the soft mimosa, Mimosa. Most likely the silk tree, Albizia julibrissin, an introduced species.
Standest thou, all lush and royaunt,
O’er each branch, and proudly cresteth
In his might the storm king twisteth
Yet each stretcheth where it listeth,
There, the cormorant, white-breasted, Cormorant, white-breasted. The white-fronted kāruhiruhi/the pied shag, or cormorant, commonly nests in coastal pōhutukawa trees.
All the seasons, in their ranging,
Thou’rt in Winter dark and massive,
In the Spring, thy leaflets springing,
Crown thee with a silver green;
While the kingfishers Kingfishers. The habitat of the kōtare/sacred kingfisher is widespread, including coastal locations, and it congregates on the coast during winter. are winging,
King of Summer Flora crowns thee,
That when sunlight on it glances
And thy flowers and leaves combining
With the good old customs chiming
Emblem, too, of strength and power,

On thy native rock; Native rock. Thomas Kirk, in The Forest Flora of New Zealand (1889), observes that pōhutukawa “has been wantonly destroyed in many localities, and is now very scarce in districts where it was formerly plentiful.”
Thou, with roots of iron cleaving
Wind and wave, for ever waving

body.p: ALFRED SHARP. Sharp. Sharpe began to spell his name without the final “e,” in accordance with the spelling used by his younger brother, William Bethal Sharp, who he joined after his move to Australia.
Newcastle. Newcastle. Sharpe had moved to Newcastle, New South Wales, in late 1887.
